Understate: The claim may be understating the extent of celebrations in Muslim nations after the 9/11 attacks, as the expert mentions that there were reports of celebrations in the Palestinian territories and possibly in Egypt as well.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support to prove that Muslim nations did not "call out" the people who celebrated the 9/11 attacks, as the expert mentions that there were no specific condemnations or chastisements from the governments of Muslim-majority nations towards those who were elated by the attacks.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim may be overlooking alternative explanations for the lack of official condemnation of the celebrations, such as cultural or political reasons that may have influenced the response of Muslim nations.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that there were official condemnations of the 9/11 attacks by Muslim nations, as mentioned by the expert.
Falters at times: The claim falters by not acknowledging that there were small-scale and localized celebrations in the Palestinian territories and possibly in Egypt, as mentioned by the expert.
Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the extent to which Muslim nations did not "call out" the people who celebrated the 9/11 attacks, as the expert mentions that there were reports of celebrations in some Muslim nations.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that Muslim nations should have officially condemned or chastised those who celebrated the 9/11 attacks, without considering potential cultural or political factors that may have influenced their response.
